executive_summary: Tom Hayes remains constructive on the market, citing a strong economy, an easing Fed, and global central bank rate cuts. He anticipates a normal 10% correction but doesn't expect a larger 20% pullback. He highlights opportunities in emerging markets, small caps, healthcare, and consumer discretionary sectors. He is extremely bullish on Alibaba, expecting it to overshoot Goldman Sachs' $280 price target. He also sees potential in Disney and National Oil Well Varco. He advises caution on crowded tech stocks and emphasizes the importance of being selective and focusing on dividend payers.

key_reasons: 316 central bank rate cuts this year
Quantitative tightening is ending in December

macro_thesis_summary: The market is in an early easing cycle with significant liquidity. The private sector has healthy balance sheets, while the public sector is meaningfully unhealthy. Emerging markets are at a secular turning point versus the US. Small caps are poised to outperform large caps. Healthcare M&A is on track for a record year. Dividend payers will dramatically outperform. Consumer sentiment is contrarian signal.

key_macro_data_points.tom_interpretation: Tops August 2010, indicating significant liquidity in the system.
Balance sheets are super healthy on the private sector side.
Meaningfully unhealthy on the public sector side.

You have to go all the way back to 20201 when everyone was chasing the concentrated stocks. They got their asses handed to them and for the next few years you dramatically outperform small caps, midcaps, international value. Same setup today.

key_macro_data_points.indicator: University of Michigan consumer sentiment index
key_macro_data_points.tom_interpretation: S&P average forward 12-month returns when you have the lowest 5% of consumer readings 12-month returns are up 18.7%. We are in the lowest 5% right now.

DIS.thesis_summary: Disney is a durable business with strong IP, poised for a turnaround driven by its experiences segment, DTC growth, and a strong film slate.
key_metrics: Revenue rose 3% to $94.44 billion for the full year
DTC just posted 1.3 billion of operating income and is on track for 10% operating margins in fiscal year 2026 after posting a $4 billion loss only three years ago.
Disney Plus added 3.8 million subscribers organically, up 3% sequentially with average revenue per user up 2% to $84.

Management is doubling planned share repurchases for fiscal year 2026. Doubling planned share repurchases, bringing total buybacks to $7 billion and is also increasing the cash dividend to $1.50 per share, up 50% year-on-year with a 1.5% yield.

BABA.thesis_summary: Alibaba is experiencing rapid growth in its cloud segment, driven by AI, and is undervalued with a strong balance sheet and significant buyback potential.
key_metrics: Cloud segment posted 34% year-on-year revenue growth
AI related product revenue accounts for more than 20% of the cloud segment's external revenue
Management has developed a 16.9 billion in capex toward AI and cloud infrastructure as part of Alibaba's three-year 53 billion capex plan.
Strong balance sheet with $80.66 billion in cash and other liquid investments

Management repurchased 2 million shares during the quarter for a total of 253 million, bringing year-to- date repurchases to $1.1 billion with 19.1 billion remaining in the authorization effective through March 2027.
BABA.action: Hold. Enjoy the ride and get some popcorn.

risks_and_contrarian_flags: Potential for a Fed 'rug pull' before the December meeting.
technical_takeaways: The Russell 2000 has a monstrous cup and handle which implies upside to 3,400. The dollar looks like it's going to break this counter trend move yet again and start to weaken once more. Expect the dollar to reverse lower in coming months, euro to reverse higher in coming months. Medical devices, medical equipment is now starting. Look at this long base. Four-year base been consolidating. There's your cup. There's your handle. Measured moves implies 36,000 to 56 implies 76,000.
